awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Secure and Privacy-Preserving Cyber-Physical Systems: Software and Hardware Approaches
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site award funds a renewal site at Tennessee Technological University focused on preparing future researchers who can protect the nation's critical infrastructure. The site's focus is on Cyber-Physical Systems (CPSs), a class of engineering systems where computation and communication network are used to monitor and control physical components. CPSs play a major role in the design and development of modern systems and initiatives, such as smart and safe cities, self-driving cars, industrial internet of things (IIoT), and smart power grid. Security breaches in CPSs can occur through software or hardware. Either one can halt critical infrastructures and reveal citizens' locations and activities, making the security of CPSs crucial for U.S. national security.

An expert group of faculty members will mentor these REU participants to conceive, design, implement, and assess research projects in the areas related to security and privacy in CPSs. The team plans to conduct nationwide recruitment efforts in partnership with Minority Serving Institutions, and to reach out to meritorious students from under-represented communities, women, students with disabilities and from institutions limited in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) research. The site will investigate both software and hardware intrinsic attacks in CPS. Undergraduate students will have the opportunity to learn diverse topics including, Blockchain for securing CPS, challenges with hardware and software attacks on IIoT, threats of adversarial learning attacks on the deployment of deep learning architectures on resource constraint hardware. Students will get exposure to different toolsets in domains such as cryptography, graph-based anomaly detection, and convolutional neural networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
In this project, 30 REU students were hired over three years. We successfully recruited ten female students, four African American student, three Hispanic student, one Native American student, and one student with disability. The main outcomes of the project are as follows.

- Outcome 1: One project created shareable privacy-preserving machine learning models instead of sharing sensitive data using mimic learning for smart health applications and the work has been published by IEEE International Conference on Informatics, IoT, and Enabling Technologies (ICIoT’20).

- Outcome 2: One project investigated an incentivized and secure firmware update and dissemination scheme for the autonomous vehicles’ (AVs) subsystems, leveraging blockchain and smart contract technology. This idea has been published in a book chapter by CRC press.

 - Outcome 3: One project has investigated the detection of Denial-of-Service (DoS) Attack in smart home Internet of Things (IoT) devices using a graph-based approach, and the idea has been published by IEEE Big Data Conference.

  - Outcome 4: One project has created a dataset for the state of charge of pure electric vehicles’ batteries using real vehicles’ routes and information provided by several automobile manufacturers on the power consumption of the electric vehicles.

- Outcome 5: The project that investigated Vulnerabilities in Elixir Programs has been accepted for publication in the ACM Southeast Conference (ACMSE) 2022. Our findings show that (i) 2.0% of the 4,446 commits are vulnerability-related, (ii) 18.0% of the 1,769 Elixir programs in our dataset are modified in vulnerability-related commits, and (iii) the proportion of vulnerability-related commits is highest in 2020. Despite Elixir being perceived as a safe language, our empirical study shows programs written in Elixir to contain vulnerabilities.

- Outcome 6: The project done by one REU student investigated the intrustion detection in the Internet of Health Things (IoHT) based on machine learning as well as graph-based anomaly detection approaches. The experiments show that machine learning techniques have higher precision, accuracy, and F1 score than graph-based techniques. However, there are aspects to a graph-based approach that could aide security experts in the discovery of certain data breaches by combining the graph-based with the statistical approaches. This work has been submitted to Florida Artificial Intelligence Research Society (FLAIRS) Conference.

- Outcome 7: One REU student explored the idea of mitigating the adversarial attacks on convolutional neural networks. This work helped in generating the required results and an IEEE Transaction paper will be submitted titled as “StAIn: Stealthy Avenues of Attacks on Horizontally Collaborated Convolutional Neural Network Inference and their Mitigation”.

- Outcome 8: An REU student worked on Trust eco-system for IoT systems against hardware attacks and resulted in the publication of a conference paper titled “InTrust-IoT: Intelligent Ecosystem based on Golden Dataset Free Power Profiling of Trusted device(s) in IoT for Hardware Trojan Detection”, in Workshop on Hardware and Architectural Support for Security and Privacy (HASP), October, 2021.

- Outcome 9: One REU student explored  hardware Trojan and its mitigation techniques. This work resulted in the accptance of a conference paper titled “A Primer on Hardware Trojans Including Platform Specific Attacks and Machine Learning for Detection” in IEEE SouthEast Conference, 2022. 

- Outcome 10: The project that investigated the effect of fan speed on the printing quality has developped a plugin called Fan Speed Attack Detection (FSAD) that predicts and monitors fan speeds throughout the printing process. This idea has been published in a journal paper in MDPI publisher.

- Outcome 11: The project that investigated techniques to manage secrets in a secure fashion has identified a method to securely store and retrieve secrets using a lookup-based method. The student developed an automated program that communicates with a lookup-based storage system called Vault. The developed program is used to conduct a tutorial for beginners.

- Outcome 12: The project done by one REU student examined whether graph-based anomaly detection is a capable and reliable method to discover botnet attacks on Internet of Things (IoT) devices. The student was able to submit a paper to the FLAIRS conference that was accepted as a short paper. Also, an improved version of this work is submitted as a regular paper to the International Conference on Data Mining (ICDM) conference.

Outcome 13. In the project done by one REU student led to a testbed generation for information leakage on IoT devices. The student wrote a technical report titled “Educational Testbed for Information Leakage in IoT Devices”, which is beneficial for future students in conducting hardware cybersecurity related research.

Outcome 14.  In a project done by one REU student, a research work was conducted on the hardware Trojan detection in untrusted devices using analog signal-based dataset using machine learning techniques. The student has written a conference paper that will be submitted to upcoming IEEE SouthEast Conference.


Last Modified: 08/12/2023
Modified by: Mohamed Mahmoud
